div1.p: Kean makes corrections to Sullivan's manuscript for a book chapter on Gorgas, including a memorandum for Ireland concerning Gorgas' military record and honors.

div1.head: Notes by Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 20, 1925

opener.dateline:
Assoc'n Military Surgeons, U.S.
OCT 20 1925 Secretary-Treasurer's Office.

div1.p:
Gorgas had nothing to do with the physical cleaning of
Havana during the year 1899 or until Feb. 10, 1900. He was
Chief Surgeon but the Sanitary Officer reported not to him
but directly to General Ludlow. He never at any time had
anything to do with cleaning the streets which was under
General (then Major) Wm. M. Black, C.E.

Carroll's infection was not due to carelessness but
was a carefully planned and executed inoculation. He was
bitten at 2 p.m., August 27, 1900 by a mosquito who had
bitten a severe case of yellow fever on the second day of
the attack 12 days before. See Reed's Preliminary Note p.8.
No Cubans. They were all believed to be immune.

The military surgeons, Reed, Havard and Kean were
quite familiar with the modus operandi of the warfare
against mosquitos. This warfare had been begun at Quemados
on Oct. 15, 1900 and in the other military camps around
Havana in consequence of G.O. No. 6 Dept. of Cuba Dec. 21st
which was before the conversion of Gorgas. His acceptance
of the role of the mosquito as of importance was certainly
after Feb. 1st, 1901. Mosquito work in Havana began in
March, 1901.

Dr. Chas. A. L. Reed's visit was not fortuitous though
very fortunate. He was sent down by Secretary Taft.

General M. W. Ireland was Surgeon General at the time
of the Armistice, November 11, 1918. General Gorgas was retired
under law when he reached his 64th Birthday on October 3, 1918.
He was placed on active duty from October 4th to December 1st so
that he could write his report, etc. but not as Surgeon General
or having any authority of command.

There is no record in the Adjutant General's Office or the
Surgeon General's Office of his having been made an Honorary
Major General in the British Army.

The records show that General Gorgas, retired Oct. 3rd 1918.
Ordered to active duty Oct. 4, 1918, under provisions of Sec. 24, Act. of
June 3, 1916, per S.O. 242, par. 101, dated Oct. 16, 1918.
Relieved from active duty Dec. 1, 1918, S.O. 269, par. 183, Nov. 16, 1918.
Received British Decoration "Order of St. Michael and St. George, 7/18/19
Received Italian Decoration “Grand Officer of the Crown of Italy”, Nov. 5, 1918.
